Original Campaign 2002

It's a lost era.  Or perhaps, a "replaced era" would be more accurate. The Original Campaign (or the "Plague Campaign") was only playable as intended for a short period, one year, before the first expansion, Shadows of Undrentide, was released the following June and changed the core game.

Join me as we travel back 15 years to play the OC as players did when Neverwinter Nights was first unveiled to eager gamers around the world.

THE SIMULATION: Play the OC as it was intended to be played.

Listed here are the ruleset elements to play very nearly as those who opened the box to install the 3 CDs.  The instructional booklet would have contained exactly what you see listed below (except for the comments).

Though some of the scripting was also modified in later releases, a player can mimic a similar challenge level by avoiding the boosts added in subsequent modifications to the core game.

These features are:

CLASSES

Limited to:

Barbarian, bard, cleric, druid, fighter, monk, paladin, ranger, rogue, sorcerer, wizard; no prestige available until SoU released; pure or multiclass are equally valid in all releases.

RACES - The original 7 races have remained unaltered from the original game.

WEAPONS

Limited to:

Simple - club, dagger, mace, sickle, spear, morningstar, quarterstaff, light/heavy crossbow, dart, sling

Martial - battleaxe, greataxe, greatsword, halberd, handaxe, heavy flail, light flail, light hammer, longbow, longsword, rapier, scimitar, shortsword, shortbow, throwing axe, warhammer

Exotic - bastard sword, dire mace, double axe, kama, katana, kukri, scythe, shuriken, two-bladed sword (weighed 4.4 lbs in 2002)

I can see where the folks playing NWN wizards in 2002 may have been challenged.  Only the fact that I've played the OC many, many times resulted in a fairly easy play-through.  Only 1 death was registered and that was death-by-dice on a 1 roll vs. a bodak gaze in Helm's Hold when Luke Whorm got just a little too close (seemed the guy was out of range of that cone but apparently not).

I had to possess my familiar a lot more than ever before.  Normally, I'd use the fairie dragon until Lvl 5 wiz, but no such luck in 2002. Still, the pixie did great and I "stole" its free ImpInvis right through the final battle to free up a slot for an extra Ice Storm or Empowered Melf arrow.  That one level 4 slot really does help early on, believe it or not.

Low AC was a factor without either Shield spell or Tumble dumps.  Eventually, it mattered less once Shadow Shield became available.  Empowered Cat Grace was a staple.  Barkskin buffs persisted until level 15, right about the time Luskan was finished.

No GMW meant the pixie dagger could never pierce Stoneskin and its ilk. And no Flame Weapon nerfed its damage even further.  Boohoo.  

The other nerf was not having Blind Fight for the Tenser attack which meant most of the shadow battles were via Melf arrows and MM, constantly kiting them into a field of Holy traps, usually just average ones.  Actually, the high skels were also tough with their SR foiling most MM and Melf arrow attempts.

But the biggest difference was trying to steer clear of those Corrupt Dragons without GS.  After trying to tie them up with a summon and the pixie so I could lay down some deadlies, I gave up (Grimgnaw was worthless, feared the moment he entered their aura cuz I forgot to drop a Clarity pot on him).  The combat icon won't stop while any of the party is fighting and the set DC is too high to set them without explosion.  Take20 makes a world of difference. Ended up just muscling through both wyrms with a fully-buffed Tenser which was easier than I had anticipated.

I ended up using Chain Lightning and Horrid Wilting alot, mostly via scrolls.  It's really important to start collecting scrolls early because the arcane library doesn't append like in HotU.  Each chapter has its own list, always scrolls of higher level than the preceding chapter.

Bless and Aid pots were also staples for the Tenser.  The +2 AB really does make fewer misses when it matters most, especially in the last 2 chapters where creatures' AC is up there and hit a whole lot harder.

The Ch4 siege golems could be killed with a combo of deadly electric/deadly holy and Delayed FB placed right about where the trap stack was.  Their regen is very high so you can't dawdle with the damage.  Without magic or traps, they are invulnerable but worth lots of XP.

Morag was a walk in the park.  Just keep dropping Horrid Wilting scrolls on the protectors and delay your slotted buffing because she'll just dispel it.  Her two hands drop to traps set in the hallway extremely fast but I can never seem to be able to coax her into the trap field.  No worries. After all the protectors are destroyed, Tenser can have its way with her.  Even Grimgnaw couldn't reach her in time for a single punch, she died so fast.

I think the hardest fight was against those blasted Chosen Lizards because I always have a hard time killing that cleric while being pounded by the minions.  If they follow into the hallway, a trap field is waiting, but the cleric always res's them the moment they die so it just wastes traps.  They always clog the doorway making it hard to get back into the room with the cleric who NEVER EVER walks into the trap field.  But with lots of scrolls of CL and Wilting, eventually the healer gets too close to his res targets and runs out of self-heals.

edit:  Almost forgot... that halberd-wielding Skrogg boss enroute to Klauth disarmed Tenser's sword just before dying.  I was wondering why all-of-a-sudden the elf's damage dropped down to very little and it turned out he was punching the Hell Hound to death and doing a fairly good job of it.  Unfortunately, the sword didn't go flying like my Risen Lord's scythe did when the Weapon Spirit in the Maker's realm stole it (back in HotU Land), so could not redeem it for mucho gold afterwards.  The very first time any of my Tensers have EVER been disarmed!   Lack of Discipline is not to be taken lightly.

Generally, the 2002 nerfs were noticeable but far from unmanageable for me. It just seemed to take longer with all the kiting and all the preemptive attacks with a possessed pixie.  I still soloed all the way, using Grimgnaw in Helm's Hold only and his presence against the Source Stone dragons, as meaningless as it turned out.  I did have him kill the last chosen lizardman because he was sulking, but that's about all he contributed.  I ended up about 4K XP short of level 19 and have no doubt that the small bit of XP sharing at the very end would have made no difference.

Playing under the 2002 limitations is a good idea for aspiring magicians because it teaches resourcefulness better than being able to reach down and essentially use cheat spells to resolve problem encounters.  But, TBH, I would have needed to buy triple the scrolls without traps at hand.  It really makes a difference and eliminates a lot of the tedium.  Besides, planning a trap field is FUN!

Hey guys!
This years OC2002 style half-orc playtrough is... a pure paladin.
Here's the build:
Spoiler
Spoiler Weapon: blessing of the daystar - the true paladin sword, however I couldn't use its +5 ench against undead, because I got it so late there were no undead enemies left nowhere... its +3 regular ench is still good, and the +1d6 fire damage against evil is a good evil detector, so I don't waste my smites. Until the point I found this I used astral blade +1 and +2 from Marrok and Barun. Armor: balduran's armor - +2 AC half-plate, but its +3 charisma is more important. +1 regen is also a nice bonus. Ring1: ring of power - some elemental resist, freedom and +1 regen... its really a powerful ring. Amulet: amu of the uthgardt - +4 str yeah, spell resist 12 meh, immun: fear... lol, pallys are already immune. Bracers: bracers of dex +4 - +4 dex, it aids the AC and the reflex saves a bit... its better than the ogre power gauntlets, because I can cast bulls, but I cant cast cats. I highly considered a bracers of armor +5 in ch4, but I stayed with the dex bracers for -1 AC but +2 reflex save (there are a lot of nasty traps in the source stone that tommy can't disarm). Helmet: greater mask of persuasion - obviously that +2 charisma was the main reason here, but that bonus to persuade was also handy.

My experiences about the build:
16 str for a pure warrior class is enough in every part of the game. If you buff your str with the best items you can find, and maybe spells, you will not have any serious problem hitting enemies. Well... maybe dragons could take a bit longer to defeat.
Smite is a fairly good ability, and extra smite is very handy when you fight against the toughest evil foes. Charisma was a bit low on lower levels, but AB was still enough to hit.
Turning is a bit useless in my opinion. There were a very few situations where I could use it effectively. Usually zombies are the best targets for turning, and skeletons are the worst. I couldnt turn a single skeleton warrior or chieftain ever because of their so high turn resistance.
Taunt was good. Even the toughest foes (dragons, balors, aribeth, maugrim, morag, etc) couldnt resist my taunts. It worked well throughout the whole game.
Persuade was also a godly skill. I could persuade almost everyone in the game for more info, higher rewards, lower prices, etc. There were only a few situations where I failed, but I think there were no option to succeed there (for example the leader of the eagle tribe in moonwood seemed to be impossible to persuade for a better reward).
Saves: they were so high because of divine grace, that in the end I usually saved against the stongest traps. Will and fort was rarely a problem also.
Lay on hands comes pretty handy if you have a high charisma. It can save your or your henchmans life in tight situations. Usually its better than a potion, because it does not provoke an AoO.

Spells:
I used the few old buffs that the OC2002 rules does not forbid. Bulls, eagles, endure/resist elements, bless, prayer, death ward. They are not gamechanging spells, but they helped a bit in the toughest fights.

I used Tommy as a hench because of his trap disarming and lockpicking skills, and his sneaks also helped me a lot. I ordered him to use his bow, this way I was really a tank, and he picked the enemies from distance. Sometimes you have to micromanage him to come closer to sneak range, but its nothing you cant handle.

Well... thats it for now. If you have questions feel free to ask them.
